scrapingNotes: Fresh scraping from Meta Ad Library - 2026-02-24. Searched by advertiser page, not keyword.

swipes.hookFramework: Engagement Bait → Profile Redirect: Uses a simple keyword comment CTA ('Comment YOUTUBE') to drive engagement, then links to Instagram profile as the conversion point. Carousel of Instagram profile links creates multiple click opportunities.
swipes.targetAudience: Online fitness coaches who follow Will Nelson's content and want to see his YouTube strategy breakdowns
swipes.whyItWorks: Extremely low-friction entry point — asking for a one-word comment feels effortless and triggers algorithmic boost from engagement. The carousel of Instagram links gives multiple chances to click through. Running since Dec 2025 suggests strong performance as an evergreen top-of-funnel engagement driver.
swipeElements: carousel format for multiple click targets

swipes.headline: Online Fitness Coaches Who Want To Scale With Predictabllitiy
swipes.hookFramework: Niche Callout → Benefit Promise: Calls out exact target audience in the headline ('Online Fitness Coaches') then promises the core desire ('Scale With Predictability'). Image-based ad with multiple versions being tested.
swipes.copyStructure: Headline callout → Benefit promise → Learn More CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Online fitness coaches doing $5-20K/mo who want predictable client acquisition
swipes.whyItWorks: The headline does all the heavy lifting — it's a precise niche callout that self-selects the right audience while simultaneously promising the #1 desire (predictable scaling). Multiple versions suggest active split-testing. The typo in 'Predictabllitiy' is either intentional pattern interrupt or untested — worth noting.
swipes.notes: Has multiple versions — active split testing

swipes.primaryText: If you've given up on Facebook ads for your fitness business… I get it. You probably blew a few thousand bucks. Got a flood of leads who couldn't afford a $20 Costco membership... let alone your high-ticket program. And you swore ads off forever. I get it… But here's the thing… If you haven't tried ads in the last YEAR... You're basing your opinion on an algorithm that doesn't even exist anymore. Facebook rolled out two MASSIVE updates just a few months ago called Andromeda and Lattice. I'm not gonna bore you with the techy details... But the short version is this: It's never been easier to attract clients who can actually afford to work with you. Not tire-kickers. Not "let me think about it" people. But actual real buyers. And that's where my company comes in. Because I've helped over 700 fitness coaches build predictable client acquisition systems using Facebook ads. And the last few months I have just never seen results like this before. We're seeing results that would've been straight-up impossible two years ago. Like Nick... Who tried ads for MONTHS with zero success, but used our system to book 15 calls that turned into $20k in sales. Or Amir... Who burned through $5K in failed ads before working with us, but within 4 days of working with us he made $7k in sales using our updated approach. Or Ryan and Danielle... Who wasted THOUSANDS on agencies that got them nothing but broke leads. But with MY ad system, they only had to spend $300 in ads to generate $7k in sales. Each of these people had FAILED with Facebook ads before. But now? They've got a predictable, reliable lead gen system that actually works. The reason they got results like this is because we built our Instagram Authority Funnel specifically around these new algorithm updates. So here's what I'm offering... Give me just 10 days to install our Instagram Authority Funnel at zero risk to you. Now... let me be clear. This is ONLY for online fitness coaches who: 1. Have great client results AND 2. Have a budget to spend on ads. If that's you... Then do this: Click the link below. Fill out a 60-second application. Book a call with me where I'll demo the Instagram Authority Funnel so you can see how it works from A to Z. And you can decide for yourself if it makes sense. Sound fair? Cool. Talk soon. -Will
swipes.hookFramework: Empathy Open → Reframe → Social Proof Stack → Risk Reversal → Application CTA: Opens by validating the reader's past failure ('I get it, you probably blew a few thousand bucks'), then reframes the problem as outdated information ('algorithm doesn't exist anymore'), introduces proprietary system with 3 specific case studies (Nick: $20K, Amir: $7K in 4 days, Ryan & Danielle: $300→$7K), offers risk reversal ('zero risk'), and closes with qualification gate.
swipes.copyStructure: Pain validation → Reframe (outdated algorithm) → Authority claim (700+ coaches) → 3 case studies with specific numbers → Proprietary system name (Instagram Authority Funnel) → Risk reversal (10 days, zero risk) → Qualification filter (2 criteria) → Application CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Online fitness coaches who have tried and failed with Facebook ads, making $5-20K/mo with proven client results, ready to invest in paid acquisition
swipes.whyItWorks: This is Will's primary long-form ad running across 5+ variations. The genius is the empathy-to-reframe structure — he doesn't argue that ads work, he validates the failure and then explains WHY it failed (old algorithm). The 3 case studies follow a 'failed before → succeeded with us' pattern that directly addresses the reader's exact objection. The qualification criteria at the end create exclusivity and filter for serious buyers. The conversational tone ('Cool. Talk soon. -Will') builds personal connection at scale.
swipeElements: empathy hook that validates past failure
3 named case studies with specific dollar amounts
before/after pattern for each case study
swipes.notes: This is Will's MAIN ad — running across 5+ creative variations with same copy. His highest-volume piece.

swipes.primaryText: You don't need more followers. You need more leads. If you've been posting content hoping it'll magically bring in clients… But all it's bringing is burnout — It's time to try something that actually scales. What you need is a system that puts your offer in front of ready-to-buy clients — every single day. We help online fitness coaches install simple ad systems that turn cold traffic into booked calls without being "famous" on Instagram. → No big audience → No viral content → No begging for DMs Just leads. Every day. 👉 Click Learn More to see how it works.
swipes.hookFramework: Contrarian Statement → Pain Point → System Promise → Anti-list: Opens with a contrarian reframe ('You don't need more followers. You need more leads.') that challenges the common content-creation hustle. Paints the pain of content burnout, then positions a systematic alternative. The anti-list (No big audience, No viral content, No begging for DMs) removes objections by negating everything the reader hates doing.
swipes.copyStructure: Contrarian hook → Pain agitation (content burnout) → System positioning → Anti-list (what you DON'T need) → Simple CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Online fitness coaches stuck in the content treadmill, posting daily but not converting, burnt out on organic social media marketing
swipes.whyItWorks: This shorter-form ad is the perfect complement to wn-003. While the long-form ad speaks to ad-skeptics, this one targets content-exhausted coaches. The contrarian opener ('You don't need more followers') challenges the dominant Instagram growth narrative. The anti-list is brilliant because it lists everything the reader is already tired of doing — making the alternative feel like relief rather than another tactic. Running across 13+ variations with video suggests this is a high-performer.
swipes.notes: Running across 13+ creative variations — clearly a top performer. Shorter than wn-003 but complementary targeting.

swipes.headline: 700+ Fitness Coaches Can't Be Wrong
swipes.primaryText: If you've given up on Facebook ads for your fitness business… I get it...
swipes.hookFramework: Social Proof Headline → Long-form Pain-to-Solution: Headline uses volume social proof ('700+ Fitness Coaches Can't Be Wrong') as an authority anchor, paired with the same long-form copy as wn-003 but with a video creative. The headline does the trust-building before the reader even starts the copy.
swipes.copyStructure: Social proof headline → Same long-form body as wn-003 → Video creative → Apply now CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Same as wn-003 — ad-skeptic fitness coaches ready for paid acquisition
swipes.whyItWorks: Same copy as wn-003 but with an authority-anchoring headline that the other versions don't have. The '700+' number is specific enough to be credible but round enough to feel impressive. Testing headline + video combination against text-only versions. 0:39 video length is ideal for attention spans.
swipes.notes: Same body copy as wn-003 but with social proof headline and video. Testing creative format.

swipes.headline: Million Dollar Client Getting System For Coaches
swipes.primaryText: You don't need more followers. You need more leads...
swipes.hookFramework: Aspirational Headline → Contrarian Body: Pairs an aspirational revenue headline ('Million Dollar Client Getting System') with the shorter contrarian body copy from wn-004. The headline sells the dream outcome while the body validates the reader's frustration.
swipes.copyStructure: Aspirational headline → Contrarian body copy → Image creative → Learn more CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Ambitious online fitness coaches who want a million-dollar system, frustrated with content marketing
swipes.whyItWorks: This variant combines the aspirational headline with the shorter, punchier body copy. The headline promises big ('Million Dollar') while the body stays grounded and relatable. Image format with description line 'The Fit Pro CEO helping clients grow their business' adds brand reinforcement. Testing image vs video with same copy.
swipes.notes: Image format variant with aspirational headline + short body copy

swipes.headline: Online Fitness Coach Who Want To Scale...
swipes.hookFramework: Niche Callout Headline → Image Creative → Direct CTA: Stripped-down version with just a niche-targeting headline and image. Minimal copy lets the creative do the talking. Testing whether the image/video alone can convert without long-form text.
swipes.copyStructure: Headline only → Image/video → Learn More CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Online fitness coaches looking to scale
swipes.whyItWorks: This minimal-copy approach tests whether Will's brand recognition and creative alone can drive clicks without the long-form persuasion. Multiple versions suggest he's testing different creatives against this same minimal headline framework.
swipes.notes: Minimal copy variant — testing creative-led conversion

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.hookFramework: Video-First Brand Introduction: Relies entirely on 1:14 video creative with minimal text. Headline is just the brand name, description is generic (Check it out now!). The video does all persuasion work — this is a brand awareness play that trusts the video content to qualify and convert.
swipes.copyStructure: Brand name headline → Video (1:14) → Generic CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Experienced fitness business owners looking to scale beyond Instagram, likely making $10K+/mo
swipes.whyItWorks: Longest-running active ad (since Jan 13) — the video carries the entire conversion burden without any supporting copy. This suggests the video content itself is highly compelling. The zero-copy approach is a bold test against their other text-heavy variations.
swipes.notes: One of the oldest active ads — running since Jan 13. Video-only persuasion.

swipes.headline: Where Elite Clients Decide
swipes.hookFramework: Aspirational Identity Headline: "Where Elite Clients Decide" positions their platform as a premium decision space, not a marketplace. The word "elite" pre-qualifies the audience and "decide" implies the clients are already high-intent — they just need to choose you.
swipes.copyStructure: Aspirational headline → Video (1:14) → Learn more CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Fitness coaches who want premium/elite clientele, frustrated with low-ticket or price-shopping leads
swipes.whyItWorks: The headline reframes the entire client acquisition game — instead of "get more clients" it is "be where the right clients already are." This appeals to the identity of coaches who see themselves as premium providers. Same video as fbm-001 but different headline framing — classic A/B test.
swipes.notes: Same video as fbm-001, testing aspirational headline vs generic

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.hookFramework: Long-Form Video Education: 2:48 video — their longest creative. Zero body copy, just brand name headline. The extended runtime suggests a mini-training or detailed case study format designed to build trust and pre-sell before the click.
swipes.copyStructure: Brand name headline → Long video (2:48) → Generic CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Fitness business owners willing to invest time watching content — signals higher buyer intent
swipes.whyItWorks: At 2:48, this is their longest video ad. People who watch long-form ads are significantly more qualified — they have demonstrated interest through attention. This serves as a pre-qualification tool, filtering for serious prospects before they ever click.
swipes.notes: Longest video creative — likely detailed training or case study

swipes.headline: Tired of Low-Paying Clients?
swipes.hookFramework: Pain-Point Question Headline: Asks the exact question their target audience is already asking themselves. "Tired of Low-Paying Clients?" is a direct pain probe that self-selects coaches who are stuck in the low-ticket grind. Video (1:51) likely presents the solution.
swipes.copyStructure: Pain question headline → Video (1:51) → Learn more CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Fitness coaches making money but stuck at low price points, charging $100-300/mo for online coaching
swipes.whyItWorks: This is their most direct pain-point headline. Running since Jan 13 alongside the aspirational headlines — testing pain-driven vs aspiration-driven messaging on the same audience. The question format triggers self-identification ("yes, that is me").
swipes.notes: Running since Jan 13 — testing pain headline vs aspirational/brand headlines

swipes.headline: When growth finally matches your competence
swipes.primaryText: Logic is no longer the barrier. It's time to align your online presence with authority and standards. You're ready for growth, but first, you need to be seen accurately - not louder or flashier, just clearly. This isn't about chasing more; it's about alignment: visibility that matches your expertise, demand that meets your high standards, and a business that reflects the life you're building now. Ready to break through? The next step isn't a sales pitch, but a conversation about elevating your professional presence. Let's explore how this works together!
swipes.hookFramework: Identity Alignment → Anti-Hype Positioning: The headline ("When growth finally matches your competence") validates the reader's belief that they deserve more. The body copy leans heavily into anti-hype language ("not louder or flashier, just clearly") which resonates with experienced coaches who are turned off by bro-marketing. Positions the consultation as "a conversation" not a "sales pitch."
swipes.copyStructure: Identity validation headline → Alignment messaging → Anti-hype positioning → Soft CTA (conversation not pitch)
swipes.targetAudience: Experienced fitness coaches who feel their business doesn't reflect their expertise level, anti-hype, values-driven professionals
swipes.whyItWorks: This is the most sophisticated copy in their arsenal. It speaks to the specific frustration of competent coaches whose revenue doesn't match their skill. The anti-hype tone ("not louder or flashier") directly positions against competitors like Will Nelson who use high-energy sales language. The soft CTA ("conversation" not "sales pitch") removes pressure and appeals to discerning buyers.
swipes.notes: Most sophisticated copy — anti-hype positioning that could resonate with LFG audience

swipes.headline: Stop Chasing Instagram Likes for Big Deals
swipes.hookFramework: Platform Contrarian → Authority Redirect: "Stop Chasing Instagram Likes for Big Deals" challenges the dominant Instagram-growth narrative and implies there's a better channel. Paired with "Where Elite Clients Decide" as the description — suggesting LinkedIn or a professional platform is the real play.
swipes.copyStructure: Contrarian headline → Authority description → Video (1:52) → Learn More CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Fitness coaches frustrated with Instagram's diminishing returns, open to alternative platforms like LinkedIn
swipes.whyItWorks: Directly attacks the Instagram hamster wheel that most fitness coaches are stuck on. The contrast between "Instagram Likes" (vanity metrics) and "Big Deals" (real revenue) creates tension. This is a platform-shift ad that positions FBM as the guide for coaches ready to graduate beyond social media.
swipeElements: vanity metrics vs real revenue contrast
swipes.notes: Anti-Instagram messaging — interesting contrast with Will Nelson who pushes Instagram Authority Funnel

swipes.headline: The Secret to LinkedIn Success
swipes.hookFramework: Curiosity Gap + Platform Specificity: "The Secret to LinkedIn Success" uses a classic curiosity gap (what's the secret?) combined with platform specificity (LinkedIn — unexpected for fitness coaches). The novelty of LinkedIn for fitness creates its own pattern interrupt.
swipes.copyStructure: Curiosity headline → Video (1:16) → Learn more CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Fitness business owners curious about LinkedIn as a client acquisition channel
swipes.whyItWorks: LinkedIn is an unexpected channel for fitness coaches, which creates natural curiosity. The "Secret" framing implies insider knowledge. Running since Jan 13 alongside their other ads — this tests whether the LinkedIn angle itself is compelling enough to drive clicks.
swipes.notes: LinkedIn angle is their unique differentiator from competitors

swipes.headline: Why referral-based growth quietly caps experienced fitness businesses
swipes.hookFramework: Problem Education Headline: Teaches the audience about a problem they didn't know they had. "Referral-based growth quietly caps" — most coaches think referrals are good, but this reframes them as a ceiling. "Quietly" is key — it implies the cap is invisible until it's too late.
swipes.copyStructure: Problem education headline → "Outgrown Instagram?" description → Video (1:32) → Learn More CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Established fitness coaches who rely on referrals and word-of-mouth, making $10-30K/mo but plateaued
swipes.whyItWorks: Brilliant reframe — referrals are universally seen as positive, but this ad reveals them as a hidden growth limiter. The word "quietly" creates unease because it implies the problem is already happening without their knowledge. Combined with "Outgrown Instagram?" description, it paints a picture of a coach who has hit multiple invisible ceilings.
swipes.notes: Best hook in their library — reframes something positive (referrals) as a hidden limiter

swipes.headline: A LinkedIn authority system built for experienced fitness founders
swipes.primaryText: Ready to stand out without screaming for attention? You're not looking for a quick fix, but a system that respects your hard work. Will it protect my reputation? Attract the right people? Feel calm instead of draining? This approach filters before attracting, clarifies before amplifying. It's not about being loud, but unmistakable. See how this works.
swipes.hookFramework: Self-Answering Objection Handler: The copy anticipates and voices the exact objections the reader has ("Will it protect my reputation? Attract the right people? Feel calm instead of draining?") then answers them. This creates an internal dialogue that feels like the ad is reading their mind. The "filters before attracting, clarifies before amplifying" line positions their approach as the opposite of volume-based marketing.
swipes.copyStructure: Question hook → Objection voicing → Principle statements → Soft CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Reputation-conscious fitness founders who fear that marketing = being loud/salesy
swipes.whyItWorks: This ad speaks directly to the coach who wants to grow but is afraid of looking desperate or salesy. By voicing their exact fears as questions, it creates deep resonance. The principle-based answer ("filters before attracting") sounds sophisticated and different from typical ad copy. The "unmistakable" vs "loud" dichotomy is memorable and shareworthy.
swipes.notes: Excellent objection-handling copy — could inspire LFG ad approach

swipes.headline: The quiet ceiling experienced coaches feel before they ever feel stuck
swipes.primaryText: You're a successful business owner, but there's an uncomfortable truth: Your growth still depends on being remembered. Inconsistent months make you hesitate. Referrals feel like a ceiling, not a strategy. Why do others with less experience seem louder and more visible? You deliver great work, but it doesn't speak loudly or consistently. Feel capped by your invisibility? Tap Learn More to understand what's really going on
swipes.hookFramework: Invisible Pain Naming → Jealousy Trigger → Identity Challenge: Names a pain the audience feels but can't articulate ("quiet ceiling"). Then hits the jealousy trigger ("Why do others with less experience seem louder?") which is deeply relatable for skilled coaches watching flashier competitors succeed. "Capped by your invisibility" is a devastating phrase that names the exact problem.
swipes.copyStructure: Invisible pain headline → Uncomfortable truth → Jealousy trigger → Identity challenge → CTA
swipes.targetAudience: Skilled but under-visible fitness coaches who watch less experienced competitors outpace them, making $10-30K/mo
swipes.whyItWorks: This is their strongest long-form copy. It names feelings the reader has never put into words — the "quiet ceiling," the frustration of watching less skilled people succeed, the gap between competence and visibility. The longest video (3:02) paired with the most emotionally resonant copy suggests this is meant to be their highest-converting piece for warm audiences. Every sentence hits a nerve.
swipes.notes: Strongest emotional copy in their library — jealousy trigger is powerful and underused
